ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Know that blessings [ni'am] are divided into those which are an ultimate end [ghaya] sought for their own sake, and into those which are sought for the sake of that end. As for the ultimate end [ghaya], it is the bliss [sa'ada] of the Hereafter [al-akhira], and its essence returns to four matters: an everlasting life [baqa'] with no annihilation, a joy [surur] with no grief within it, a knowledge ['ilm] with no ignorance accompanying it, and a richness [ghina] with no poverty after it. This is the true blessing [al-ni'ma al-haqiqiyya]. As for the means [wasail], they are divided into: the nearest and most specific, such as the virtues [fada'il] of the soul [nafs]; and into what is next in proximity, such as the virtues of the body [badan], which is the second; and into what is next in proximity and extends beyond the body, such as the encompassing causes [asbab] surrounding the body, from wealth [mal], family [ahl], and kin ['ashira]; and into what combines these external causes with what is attained for the soul [nafs], such as divine facilitation [tawfiq] and guidance [hidaya]. They are, therefore, four types: The first type, which is the most specific: the spiritual virtues [al-fada'il al-nafsiyya]. Their essence, despite the branching of their aspects, returns to faith [iman] and good character [husn al-khuluq]. Faith [iman] is divided into the knowledge of unveiling ['ilm al-mukashafa], which is knowledge of God Almighty, His attributes, His angels, and His messengers; and into the sciences of interaction ['ulum al-mu'amala]. Good character [husn al-khuluq] is divided into two parts: abandoning the demands of base desires [shahawat] and anger [ghadab], and its name is chastity ['iffa]; and observing justice ['adl] in restraining from the demands of desires and in proceeding, so that one does not abstain completely nor proceed however one wishes. Rather, his proceeding and holding back should be by the just scale [al-mizan al-'adl] which God Almighty sent down upon the tongue of His Messenger, peace be upon him. For God Almighty has said: "That you not transgress in the measure [al-mizan]. And establish weight in justice [al-qist] and do not make deficient the measure [al-mizan]." (55:8-9) So whoever castrates himself to remove the desire for intercourse, or who abandons intercourse despite having the capability and security from harms, or who abandons eating until he becomes weak for worship, remembrance [dhikr], and reflection [fikr] has indeed made deficient the measure [al-mizan]. And whoever plunges into the desires of the belly and the private parts has transgressed in the measure [al-mizan]. Justice ['adl] is only that his weighing and estimation be free from transgression [tughyan] and deficiency [khusran], so that the two pans of the scale [al-mizan] are balanced by it.

And the desire (Shahwa) is an expression of the movement of his walking army. This is because Satan was created from fire, and the human being (al-Insan) was created from clay (Salsal) like pottery (al-Fakhkhar). And pottery has gathered in it with fire the clay (al-Tin), and the clay's nature is stillness (al-Sukun), and fire's nature is movement (al-Haraka). So one cannot imagine a burning fire that does not move; rather, it continues to move by its nature. Indeed, when intimacy [uns] with the remembrance of Allah, the Exalted, is attained, one is severed from all besides the remembrance of Allah. For all besides Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, is what will depart from him at death. There will not remain with him in the grave any family, nor wealth, nor children, nor authority. Nothing will remain except the remembrance of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. If he had found intimacy with it, he will delight in it and take pleasure in the removal of the distracting obstacles that turned him away from it, for the necessities of needs in the life of this lower world [al-hayat al-dunya] divert one from the remembrance of Allah. After death, no obstacle remains. It is as if he is left alone with his Beloved, so his bliss is immense, and he is freed from the prison in which he was prevented from that with which he found intimacy. For this reason, He, peace be upon him, said: "Indeed, the Spirit of Holiness [Ruh al-Qudus] inspired in my heart [raw'i]: 'Love whom you love, for you will be parted from him.'" He meant by this everything pertaining to the lower world [al-dunya], for that perishes in relation to him through death: "All upon it will perish, and there will remain the Face of your Lord, Possessor of Majesty and Honor." The lower world [al-dunya] only perishes for him through death, until it perishes in itself when the term of the Decree reaches its end. This intimacy [uns] is what the servant delights in after his death, until he descends into the neighborhood of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and ascends from remembrance [dhikr] to the Meeting [liqa']. That is after what is in the graves is scattered forth and what is in the breasts is made manifest. Let no one deny the permanence of the remembrance of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, with him after death, saying, "He has been annihilated, so how can the remembrance of Allah remain with him?" For he has not been annihilated with an annihilation that prevents remembrance [dhikr]. Rather, it is an annihilation from the lower world [al-dunya] and the realm of dominion and the visible world ['alam al-mulk wa al-shahadah], not from the realm of sovereignty ['alam al-malakut].

In tents of moist white pearl, with spreads of green brocade, reclining on couches set at the edges of rivers flowing with wine and honey, surrounded by youths and young boys, adorned with the wide-eyed houris (Al-Hur Al-'Ayn) from the beautiful maidens, as if they were ruby and coral, whom no human (Ins) has touched before them, nor any jinn (Jann), walking in the degrees of Paradise; when one of them sways in her walk, seventy thousand young boys carry her flanks, upon her are fine white silks that dazzle the eyes, crowned with tiaras studded with pearl and coral, shapely, coquettish, fragrant, secure from aging and misery, secluded in the tents in palaces of ruby built amidst the meadows of Paradise, restraining their gaze (Qasirat Al-Tarf), then they are served, and upon them, with cups and ewers and a cup from a flowing spring, white, a delight for the drinkers, and servants and young boys like hidden pearls circulate among them, a reward for what they used to do, in a secure station, in gardens and springs, in gardens and a river, in a seat of truth near an Omnipotent Sovereign (Malik Muqtadir); they look therein at the face of the Noble King (Al-Malik Al-Karim), and the radiance of bliss has shone upon their faces, no weariness nor humiliation afflicts them, but rather honored servants (Ibad Mukramun), and with various gifts from their Lord they are attended, so they are in what their souls (Anfus) desire, abiding forever, they fear not therein nor grieve, and they are secure from the doubt of death, so they therein enjoy bliss and eat from its foods and drink from its rivers milk and wine and honey, in rivers of its lands of silver and its gravel is coral, and upon its ground its dust is fragrant musk and its plants are saffron, and they are rained upon from clouds therein from water of narcissus upon dunes of camphor, and they are brought cups, and what cups, cups of silver studded.
